question: In the case of Nasr v NRMA Insurance [2006] NSWSC 1018, why was the plaintiff's appeal lodged out of time?
accepted_response: The court found the plaintiff lodged the appeal out of time because he misunderstood the legal advice regarding the deadline.
rejected_response: The plaintiff's appeal was lodged out of time because an incorrect belief that the decision was not yet final was held by the plaintiff's legal representatives.

question: In the case of R v NGUYEN [2001] NSWCCA 334, what was the relationship between the Appellant and Mr Nguyen, and what activities of Mr Nguyen did the Appellant testify about?
accepted_response: In R v NGUYEN [2001] NSWCCA 334, the Appellant, serving as a co-offender, testified about Mr Nguyen's involvement in drug trafficking activities.
rejected_response: In the case of R v NGUYEN [2001] NSWCCA 334, it was testified by the Appellant that the relationship held was that of an acquaintance with Mr Nguyen, and the activities related to drug trafficking were those about which Mr Nguyen's involvement was spoken of by the Appellant.

question: In the case of Moore v Scenic Tours Pty Ltd [2015] NSWSC 237, what was the court's decision regarding the motion to restrain a firm from acting?
accepted_response: The court denied the motion to restrain the firm from acting in the case of Moore v Scenic Tours Pty Ltd [2015] NSWSC 237.
rejected_response: In the case of Moore v Scenic Tours Pty Ltd [2015] NSWSC 237, the motion to restrain a firm from acting was denied by the court.

question: What were the circumstances and outcomes of the case Inspector Phillip Estreich v Hannas Civil Engineering Pty Ltd and Afram Hanna [2009] NSWIRComm 168 in New South Wales?
accepted_response: The New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission found Hannas Civil Engineering Pty Ltd and Afram Hanna guilty of failing to ensure the safety of a worker, resulting in a fine of $225,000 and $22,500 respectively in the case Inspector Phillip Estreich v Hannas Civil Engineering Pty Ltd and Afram Hanna [2009] NSWIRComm 168.
rejected_response: In the case of Inspector Phillip Estreich v Hannas Civil Engineering Pty Ltd and Afram Hanna [2009] NSWIRComm 168, it was found by the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission that breaches of the Occupational Health and Safety Act 2000 had been committed by Hannas Civil Engineering Pty Ltd and Afram Hanna, and fines totalling $180,000 were imposed.

question: In the case of Ruddock v Vadarlis [2001] FCA 1329, what was the argument of the Commonwealth regarding the application of habeas corpus and how was it received?
accepted_response: In Ruddock v Vadarlis [2001] FCA 1329, the Commonwealth argued that habeas corpus did not apply to the detainees as they were outside Australia's migration zone, and the court accepted this argument.
rejected_response: In the case of Ruddock v Vadarlis [2001] FCA 1329, the argument that the application of habeas corpus did not extend to non-citizens being detained offshore was made by the Commonwealth, and it was upheld by the court.

question: When did the Poisons List Amendment Order 2012 come into effect in Tasmania?
accepted_response: The Poisons List Amendment Order 2012 took effect in Tasmania on October 1, 2012.
rejected_response: The Poisons List Amendment Order 2012 was brought into effect in Tasmania on 1st January 2013.

question: Who were the defendants in the case Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Letten (No 24) [2014] FCA 1322?
accepted_response: In the case Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Letten (No 24) [2014] FCA 1322, Mark Ronald Letten served as the defendant.
rejected_response: In the case Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Letten (No 24) [2014] FCA 1322, Mark Ronald Letten and others were identified as the defendants.

question: What changes were made in the amendment AD/BAe 146/104 Amdt 1 to the British Aerospace BAe 146 Series Aeroplanes Airworthiness Directive?
accepted_response: The amendment AD/BAe 146/104 Amdt 1 introduced a requirement for repetitive inspections of the wing's rear spar upper boom and the detailed inspection of the fuselage frames 40 and 41 for cracks on the British Aerospace BAe 146 Series Aeroplanes.
rejected_response: In the amendment AD/BAe 146/104 Amdt 1 to the British Aerospace BAe 146 Series Aeroplanes Airworthiness Directive, the inspection intervals were revised and the applicability was expanded to include additional serial numbers.

question: What is the landlord's general obligation under section 63 of the Act in the case of Anderson v Armitage [2014] NSWCATCD 157 in New South Wales?
accepted_response: Under section 63 of the Act, the landlord must ensure the rented premises are in a reasonable state of repair, considering the property's age and the amount of rent, as established in Anderson v Armitage [2014] NSWCATCD 157 in New South Wales.
rejected_response: Under section 63 of the Act, in the case of Anderson v Armitage [2014] NSWCATCD 157 in New South Wales, it is required that the premises be maintained in a reasonable state of repair by the landlord.

question: What were the two certifications contained in the Certificate in the case of Pauga v Samoa [2022] FCA 1097?
accepted_response: The Certificate in Pauga v Samoa [2022] FCA 1097 contained two certifications: firstly, that Pauga was an extraditable person under the Extradition Act 1988 (Cth), and secondly, that the extradition offense was an extradition offense under the same act.
rejected_response: In the case of Pauga v Samoa [2022] FCA 1097, it was certified that, firstly, the requirements of section 15B of the Extradition Act 1988 (Cth) had been complied with and, secondly, that the person could be surrendered under the Act.

question: In the case of Alan John Hyland (as Executor of the Estate of the late Lily Therese Hyland) v Jacqueline Sheri Woods [2011] NSWSC 266, what was the court's decision regarding the distribution of the monies in the Commonwealth Bank of Australia fixed deposit account?
accepted_response: The court decided that Jacqueline Sheri Woods must return the monies from the Commonwealth Bank of Australia fixed deposit account to the estate of the late Lily Therese Hyland.
rejected_response: In the case of Alan John Hyland (as Executor of the Estate of the late Lily Therese Hyland) v Jacqueline Sheri Woods [2011] NSWSC 266, it was decided by the court that the monies in the Commonwealth Bank of Australia fixed deposit account were to be distributed to Jacqueline Sheri Woods.

question: What is the test for determining a "genuine" dispute or claim in the context of section 459H, as interpreted by Australian Commonwealth courts?
accepted_response: Australian Commonwealth courts apply the test of whether there is a serious question to be tried or a plausible contention requiring investigation to determine if a dispute or claim is "genuine" under section 459H.
rejected_response: In the context of section 459H, a "genuine" dispute or claim is determined by whether a plausible contention requiring investigation is presented, as has been interpreted by Australian Commonwealth courts.

question: What were the charges against the applicant in the case of R v Perry [2000] NSWCCA 375 in New South Wales?
accepted_response: The court charged the applicant in R v Perry [2000] NSWCCA 375 with drug trafficking offenses.
rejected_response: In the case of R v Perry [2000] NSWCCA 375 in New South Wales, the applicant was charged with murder and attempted murder.

question: In the context of the Anti-Discrimination Act (AD Act) in New South Wales, how is the term "incite" interpreted in relation to the offence of serious racial vilification?
accepted_response: Under the Anti-Discrimination Act in New South Wales, "incite" in the context of serious racial vilification refers to promoting, urging, or spurring others to hate or have serious contempt for, or severe ridicule of, a person or group of people based on their race.
rejected_response: In relation to the offence of serious racial vilification under the Anti-Discrimination Act in New South Wales, the term "incite" is interpreted as encouraging or urging others to feel hatred towards, contempt for, or severe ridicule of a person or group of people because of their race.

question: What was the final decision of the court in the case of Colbron v Freeman (No 2) [2014] NSWSC 1528 in New South Wales?
accepted_response: The court found in favor of Freeman in the case of Colbron v Freeman (No 2) [2014] NSWSC 1528.
rejected_response: In the case of Colbron v Freeman (No 2) [2014] NSWSC 1528 in New South Wales, a judgement in favor of the defendant was rendered by the court.

question: Under the Criminal Assets Recovery Act 1990 (NSW), what powers does the New South Wales Crime Commission have in relation to restraining orders and property control?
accepted_response: Under the Criminal Assets Recovery Act 1990 (NSW), the New South Wales Crime Commission can apply for restraining orders against property and control property suspected of being linked to criminal activities.
rejected_response: Under the Criminal Assets Recovery Act 1990 (NSW), the power to issue restraining orders and to take control of property is possessed by the New South Wales Crime Commission.

question: Under the Business Services Wage Assessment Tool Payment Scheme Amendment Act 2016 (Cth), what is the Secretary required to do if a person's application for a payment under the BSWAT payment scheme was refused before the commencement day due to a determination that the payment amount for the person was nil?
accepted_response: Under the Business Services Wage Assessment Tool Payment Scheme Amendment Act 2016 (Cth), the Secretary must reconsider the person's application if it was refused before the commencement day because the determination found the payment amount for the person to be nil.
rejected_response: Under the Business Services Wage Assessment Tool Payment Scheme Amendment Act 2016 (Cth), it is required by the Secretary that the application of a person, which was refused before the commencement day due to a determination that the payment amount for the person was nil, be reconsidered.

question: In the case of Angela Therese Harvey (nee Alecci) v Eileen Therese Alecci & Anor [2002] NSWSC 898, what was the court's decision regarding the order for mediation?
accepted_response: The court ordered mediation between the parties in the case of Angela Therese Harvey (nee Alecci) v Eileen Therese Alecci & Anor [2002] NSWSC 898.
rejected_response: In the case of Angela Therese Harvey (nee Alecci) v Eileen Therese Alecci & Anor [2002] NSWSC 898, an order for mediation was made by the court.

question: In the case of Singh v MIMA [1998] FCA 1240, what was the main argument presented by the applicant for review of the Refugee Review Tribunal's decision?
accepted_response: In Singh v MIMA [1998] FCA 1240, the applicant argued that the Refugee Review Tribunal erred in its decision by not properly considering the credibility of his fear of persecution.
rejected_response: In the case of Singh v MIMA [1998] FCA 1240, the main argument for the review of the Refugee Review Tribunal's decision was presented by the applicant as being based on an alleged failure by the Tribunal to properly consider the applicant's fear of persecution for reasons of his political opinion.

question: In the case of Carvajal v Lamba [2019] NSWDC 284, did the court draw any adverse inference against the plaintiff for not mentioning certain details about the accident in her initial descriptions?
accepted_response: Yes, the court drew an adverse inference against the plaintiff for not mentioning certain details about the accident in her initial descriptions in Carvajal v Lamba [2019] NSWDC 284.
rejected_response: In the case of Carvajal v Lamba [2019] NSWDC 284, an adverse inference was indeed drawn by the court against the plaintiff for the failure to mention certain details about the accident in her initial descriptions.
